nodes.text: Hypothetical bias in choice experiments (CEs) systematically affects external validity: choices elicited in hypothetical settings can deviate from choices in more realistic settings, with effects that are context- and measurement-dependent

Method: systematic, multidisciplinary literature search in Web of Science and supplementary searches produced a core dataset of 57 peer-reviewed CE studies empirically testing hypothetical bias, plus a supplementary set from psychology and neuroscience
Result: Overall empirical evidence is mixed — many studies find significant hypothetical bias, many find negligible bias, and many report mixed results depending on metric or design

Evidence: Health-economics CE studies (predominantly within-subject, benchmarked against real choices) mostly report negligible or small hypothetical bias and reasonably high predictive sensitivity for opt-in behaviour

Evidence: Consumer-economics CE studies often report significant upward hypothetical bias in opt-in rates and total WTP, though marginal WTP estimates are sometimes robust after corrections; incentive-aligned designs and enhanced tangibility can reduce bias

Evidence: Transport-economics CE studies commonly find significant bias, often a downward bias in monetary valuation of travel time savings, though non-monetary transport choices sometimes show no bias

Evidence: Environmental CE studies report mixed findings; some show congruence after scale adjustment while others find large differences for certain measures like trip counts or donation opt-in rates

Claim: Scale differences between hypothetical and more realistic datasets are a consistent empirical observation and must be accounted for when comparing marginal rates of substitution or parameter estimates
Method: studies used a five-class conceptualisation of benchmark realism (Class I online hypothetical to Class V naturalistic revealed data) to characterise degrees of realism for comparisons

Limitation: Benchmarks vary widely (from incentivised lab choices to naturalistic revealed data); lack of a universal 'true preference' benchmark and heterogeneous operationalisations of hypothetical bias impede consistent measurement and meta-synthesis

Claim: Specific observed patterns — opt-in rates and total willingness-to-pay (TWTP) are frequently biased, while hypothetical marginal rates of substitution or marginal WTP may be less biased after scale correction

Claim: Sources and psychological mechanisms underlying hypothetical bias include lack of incentive consequentiality (payment and policy), social desirability and warm-glow, strategic misrepresentation, cognitive dissonance/choice-induced preference change, hot-cold empathy gaps, lack of familiarity and absence of dynamic learning, and design-induced cognitive shortcuts

Evidence from psychology and neuroimaging: fMRI and behavioral experiments show (a) common valuation areas engage in both real and hypothetical choices but often with stronger activation in real choices, (b) hot-cold empathy gaps and affective state differences can reverse bias direction for aversive versus appetitive goods, and (c) contextual richness reduces gaps

Claim: Moderating factors that systematically influence the magnitude or direction of hypothetical bias include type of good (public/private, moral/neutral, desirable/aversive), design (within vs between, opt-out inclusion, incentive alignment), payment vehicle, stake size, attribute salience and respondent characteristics (gender, familiarity, personality)

Conclusion: Hypothetical bias is an undeniable component of external validity concerns for CEs but does not invalidate CEs; careful design, appropriate benchmark selection across degrees of realism, scale correction, and targeted mitigation can make CEs useful for policy and valuation

Claim: The authors propose a unified definition: hypothetical bias in CEs is the deviation in a predefined aggregate or disaggregate measure due to collecting choice data in a hypothetical setting instead of a more realistic (not necessarily naturalistic) setting
